Closed issue "[Epic]Deprecate http usage: Promote from warning to error" (#13289) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

NuGet.exe, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

We have [NU1803](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu1803) warnings across NuGet. Promote from warning to error.

- [x] [Promote from warning to error in restore scenarios](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13353)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in push operations](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13342)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in delete operations](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13341)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in search package](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13316)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in list package](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13323)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in source command](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13333)
- [x] [Promote from warning to error in VS Options NuGet Package Manager](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13354)
- [ ] [Show an error when a non https source is used in a resource in a service index](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13364)
- [x] [Add `--allow-insecure-connections` option to dotnet.exe](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/13396)

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "The same package source gets two different tooltips" (#4330) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**NuGet Version:** NuGet 4.0.0-RTM-2224
**VS Version:** D15Rel 26118.00
**OS Version:** Windows 10 RS1_Release 14393.726.170112-1758
 
**Repro Steps:**
1.  Create a new C# Console Application via VS.
2.  Right-click on the project and click ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’.
3.  Hover on ‘Package source’ drop down list on the right-top of PM UI (default is ‘nuget.org’).
4.  Switch to other package source and switch back to ‘nuget.org’.
5.  Hover on ‘Package source’ drop down list again.

**Expected Result:**
The same package source gets same tooltips between step3 and step5.

**Actual Result:**
The same package source gets two different tooltips as below screenshot.
![differenttooltips](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20632625/22099600/f73c8172-de66-11e6-88d7-b6f6f11f8889.png)

**Note:**
1. It repro on D15Rel 26118.00 (NuGet Client 4.0.0-RC3-2215).
2. It also repro on Dev14 MU3.5 25421.01(NuGet 3.4.4.1321).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VSTHRD003: Investigate whether the flagged code can lead to deadlocks" (#8976) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
More info here: https://github.com/microsoft/vs-threading/blob/master/doc/analyzers/VSTHRD003.md

Tasks that are created and run from another context (not within the currently running method or delegate) should not be returned or awaited on. 

The specific code is https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/cb402b5a3340ab5b2605ecc72de7f70aaac95344/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio/PackageFeeds/MultiSourcePackageMetadataProvider.cs#L161-L167. 

I started the investigation, but the scope of it larger than I anticipated so I decided to create a dedicated issue for future investigations. 

I also analyzed our data for potential deadlocks that could be root caused to this but was not able to find any, so I think this has lower priority.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allocation Spike/GC Pause: NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.BuildAssetsFile" (#9261) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
With a median allocation rate of 152.0 Mb/s, in 2121 cabs, representing 4.57 percent of cabs analyzed
NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.BuildAssetsFile
has been identified as a blame candidate for an allocation spike.

Worst case example: 1633.0 Mb/s for 1000.0 ms ending at 27095.644192503503:

Most recent example: 253.0 MB/s for 1000.0 ms ending at 3372.8011: 

Stats from Worst Case cab: 708.0 ms spent in GC
GCReasons: ["AllocSmall:151"] GcTypes: ["NonConcurrentGC:151"]

Types Allocated: ["System.String:3469 System.String","System.Int32[]:3135 System.Int32[]","System.String[]:1546 System.String[]","Enumerator[Microsoft.Extensions.FileSystemGlobbing.Internal.IPatternContext]:1297 Enumerator[Microsoft.Extensions.FileSystemGlobbing.Internal.IPatternContext]","System.Char[]:773 System.Char[]"]

Other Blame Candidates Seen:["NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand+<ExecuteAsync>d__32.MoveNext:4","NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.BuildAssetsFile:4","Microsoft.Extensions.FileSystemGlobbing.Internal.MatcherContext.Match:3","NuGet.Commands.LockFileBuilder.CreateLockFile:2","NuGet.Commands.LockFileUtils.CreateLockFileTargetLibrary:2","NuGet.Commands.LockFileUtils.AddAssets:2","NuGet.Commands.LockFileUtils.AddContentFiles:1"]

Steve J Steiner, [958533]()

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024" (#72) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as April 8th, 2024. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by April 8th, 2024 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org that are signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-april-8th-2024/
